context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So what if there is some person who has, you know, the best sense of smell in the department, and they say, well, let's use him to go do the knock and talks when we suspect drugs; that way, he may discover the odor of marijuana when other people wouldn't.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Is it -- is it -- is it wrong for them to select the person with the best sense of smell to do that?

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: It's the defendant's misconduct which keeps the plaintiff from knowing of her cause of action.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Counsel, you made the point earlier that it would be very odd that it's only the sovereign that doesn't benefit from the discovery rule when other people can.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: You know, the sovereign, with all of its resources, can decide to go after whomever it discovers, however many years after -- whether it's the Social Security recipient that Justice Breyer mentioned or anyone else.

context.text: So I at least don't find it unusual that it's the sovereign in particular that doesn't get the benefit of whenever you happen to find about it rule.

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: No question in the typical case, but what equity has always said is in cases of fraud or concealment the defendant is not entitled to repose until there is discovery of the fraud.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Its purpose is to root out fraud, and the SEC has many legal weapons on hand to do so.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The Government also seeks a different kind of relief in these cases.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The discovery rule helps to ensure that the injured are compensated, but this case involves penalties which go beyond compensation are intended to punish and label defendants as wrong doers.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Chief Justice Marshall said over 200 years ago that it “Would be utterly repugnant to the genius of our laws if actions for penalties could be brought at any distance of time.”

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Now, with language like that, you get the sense that he meant it.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Applying the discovery rule here would raise similar concerns.

context.speaker: Ronald Mann
context.text: --Well, I don't think our position depends on Rule 68 at all for the mootness.

context.speaker: Ronald Mann
context.text: Our position for the mootness is that if there's no further controversy about the relief that is created by the cause of action, there's nothing more for the trial court to do--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Let me ask you this--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Let me ask you just this question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Just tell me as a matter of common practice, do district courts enter judgments against plaintiffs routinely when a full offer of settlement has been made and the defendant just is silent?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Your offer says you hereby offer to allow entry of judgment under Rule 68.

context.speaker: Ronald Mann
context.text: --But we don't think that the mootness of the case flows from Rule 68.

context.speaker: Ronald Mann
context.text: The mootness of the case flows from the fact that there is not a dispute between the parties about anything a Federal court can handle.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But the question from Justice Alito was, what happens; does the court have authority to have a hearing?

context.speaker: Ronald Mann
context.text: But the court--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And you said, oh, well, this is not under Rule 68; but, you offered to allow entry of judgment under Rule 68.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: That's precisely right.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Let's go from there, at least with me, and that may answer an earlier question about an inquest on damages, because that is a part of the requirements for a default judgment, so that if there is a dispute about damages that can be resolved.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: But my point is that liability is admitted.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Now let's deal with the Chief's question and Justice Scalia's question, which is in what ways is this comparable to a shared cost like what motivated our decision in class actions, that the settlement of one existing plaintiff doesn't settle the collective action.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: How is this similar to that?

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: So we think that the corpus of cases that this Court has handled in the class action area such as Geraghty and Gerstein and the like, we don't think that they absolutely control this question.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: It may well be that there was payment.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: It could -- there could be accord and satisfaction.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I'm not sure I understand.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: You think there is a live case, not if he doesn't cash it, but I guess as Justice Breyer was asking, if it's a day late?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: You -- you said, well, there was a past injury, it was a day late, it -- it, you know, could be redressed by telling him what?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Pay him again?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Thomas has our opinion this morning in case 11-1059, Genesis HealthCare versus Symczyk.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: This case comes to us on a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit and I don't have good news for them either.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, FLSA, provides that an employee may bring an action to recover damages for specified violations on behalf of himself and other similarly situated employees.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Third, respondent argues that the purposes of the FLSAs collective action provisions could be frustrated by strategic settlement offers designed to pick off named plaintiffs before a collective action can run its course.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: But this policy concern cannot overcome the constitutional requirement that the named plaintiff maintain a personal stake throughout the action.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Because respondent cannot show that she maintained a personal stake in the suit and once her individual claim became moot, we conclude that the District Court was correct to dismiss the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Justice Kagan has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justices Ginsburg, Breyer, and Sotomayor joined.

context.speaker: Jane Webre
context.text: The PTO--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Or the district court does, if it gets to review that in a later action.

context.speaker: Jane Webre
context.text: --Well, but--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I'm only raising this question to address Justice Scalia's point.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: You're asking for an absolute rule, and I posited a situation where I think it's not so clear that a State court finding might not have an effect.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So, do we have to go to your absolute rule?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I would find it extraordinary for that to be the rule.

context.speaker: Thomas M. Michel
context.text: --Well, you can't isolate it.

context.speaker: Thomas M. Michel
context.text: That rule is more complicated because it is the application of the Grable standard that's the analysis.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But getting back, Justice Ginsburg simply made the point, I had thought, that you place a good deal of reliance on the fact that there is exclusive jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And her question to me pointed out how far-reaching this case might be because it could involve patents, copyright, all other areas of exclusive jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: If that is going to be your special rule, it's not so confined as you suggest.

context.speaker: Thomas M. Michel
context.text: Breaches of fiduciary duty for divestiture of fees does not have a causation element.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: So you are talking about a patent case that has a patent issue, whether it's a contract case, a tort case, a malpractice case -- if it has a patent issue, you think it has to go to Federal court.

context.speaker: Thomas M. Michel
context.text: We do not.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, then I repeat Justice Ginsburg's question, how do you decide which of those do and which of those don't?

context.speaker: Thomas M. Michel
context.text: I think this is a case in point.

context.speaker: Thomas M. Michel
context.text: This case is on all fours with Grable.

context.speaker: Thomas M. Michel
context.text: It's also the duty and the obligation of the lawyer to disclose that judicial discussion to the Patent Office.

context.speaker: Thomas M. Michel
context.text: Otherwise his continuation patent could be declared invalid for inequitable conduct, for not disclosing material information.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And your -- your distinction between other areas of Federal jurisdiction where the Federal law controls and patent is what?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Sotomayor brought up immigration law--

context.speaker: Thomas M. Michel
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --copyright law.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Makes sense, right?

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: Well, I believe the Supreme Court has, under its own special rules, the -- the ability to take an argument in -- a petition that has not been raised before, but on its own could accept it if it is clear at the time--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But then what your -- your first answer was that this is a very small set of cases that you're dealing with.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: If your answer to Justice Scalia is yes, this Court could take a case that's unsettled and, by settling it, make the error plain.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: That would open the door to a huge number of cases, wouldn't it?

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: --I don't believe so, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: I believe that the provisions to get to the Supreme Court -- frankly, I don't know the answer as to if you had skipped the -- the appellate court, and -- and we're still in that window of time, that transition period after the appellate court had ruled, and only then the clarifying error came, I think you could still come to the Supreme Court.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: But the very narrow -- the very narrow--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, it would be narrow in the sense that substantial rights would have to be affected and the other conditions of Olano on that.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But I think, consequent on Justice Scalia's question is, that itself would be another issue in every case.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Is this one of those cases: Number one, it was wrong; number two, it's new; number three, is it clear under all the Olano criteria.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And that would have to be decided in every case.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: It's to -- it's to correct a very serious wrong, an injustice that was incurred by the defendant.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: That's the primary purpose of 52(b).

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: And then, if you look at it the way the court would -- the solicitors would have -- have the court decide at time of trial, there would be no remedy for--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But -- but there's -- this brings you back to Justice Alito's question.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: There's always an injustice when the district court has gotten it wrong.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The district court got it wrong, applied the wrong rule.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: The practitioner can now come and say, my client has a clear error.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: Tapia has now been decided, and it is clear.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: It was only unclear and unsettled at the time we were in court.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I suppose one answer to Justice Scalia's question is that, well, if you require an objection, and you have to have a laundry list of everything that might change, the -- the answer to that, in turn, is, if -- if you use that rationale, then we're just asking the attorney to conceal from the judge every -- everything that's important.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: Well--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It would seem to me the laundry list, even though that's perhaps an initial objection to Justice Scalia's concern, is, frankly, preferable to a system where we just don't -- don't talk about what might be clear error.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: It was only unclear and unsettled at the time we were in court.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I suppose one answer to Justice Scalia's question is that, well, if you require an objection, and you have to have a laundry list of everything that might change, the -- the answer to that, in turn, is, if -- if you use that rationale, then we're just asking the attorney to conceal from the judge every -- everything that's important.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: Well--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It would seem to me the laundry list, even though that's perhaps an initial objection to Justice Scalia's concern, is, frankly, preferable to a system where we just don't -- don't talk about what might be clear error.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: --Well, I think we must talk about clear error.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: And -- and I think that in my -- my briefing, in my -- in my beginning to the closing brief, and certainly in the amicus brief, which is an excellent source on this point, when the Court looked at both -- 52(b) in both Olano and Johnson, they looked to the text, that this Court looked to the text of 52(b).

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: And I think that was just a couple of lines after acknowledging the fact that the petitioner said, well, it would have been a laundry list, and that's inconvenient, and it's futile, and it's a waste of time.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: But that, I think, was more of an argument that went along with what the Chief Justice wrote, that we're looking at the text, and it just doesn't make any sense.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: We've got Olano that says, at the very minimum, the error must be clear at the time of appeal.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I want to go back to Justice Alito's question for a moment because I thought -- and Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I thought, in your brief, you -- you said that their point's a good point.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Their point is that the system works in a way that requires the lawyer to object at the trial.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: And I think that was just a couple of lines after acknowledging the fact that the petitioner said, well, it would have been a laundry list, and that's inconvenient, and it's futile, and it's a waste of time.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: But that, I think, was more of an argument that went along with what the Chief Justice wrote, that we're looking at the text, and it just doesn't make any sense.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: We've got Olano that says, at the very minimum, the error must be clear at the time of appeal.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I want to go back to Justice Alito's question for a moment because I thought -- and Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I thought, in your brief, you -- you said that their point's a good point.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Their point is that the system works in a way that requires the lawyer to object at the trial.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So if all that's at stake is a resentencing, not much harm is done, and you're more likely to satisfy the fourth.

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: And the third.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: If what's at stake is a whole new trial and everything, it's probably a little bit harder to satisfy that prong.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So it's possible to build what Justice Kennedy was referring to into the present rule, isn't it?

context.speaker: Patricia A. Gilley
context.text: It could -- it could be possible, and it could be--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Why -- why is that so?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Wall.

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court:

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: The contemporaneous--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Was Justice Breyer essentially correct that in most of the cases where an error is not plain at the time of trial that the third and fourth prong of Olano almost always take care of the issue?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I mean, I've been looking for a case in this Court in which more substantial errors than the one that occurred here -- we are going to put aside the fact that I don't see how this Defendant on the third or fourth could ever win, given that he was begging for drug treatment during his sentencing, so how a resentence would affect the fairness or integrity of this proceeding is beyond my understanding.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: But isn't Justice Breyer right?

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: The contemporaneous--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Was Justice Breyer essentially correct that in most of the cases where an error is not plain at the time of trial that the third and fourth prong of Olano almost always take care of the issue?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I mean, I've been looking for a case in this Court in which more substantial errors than the one that occurred here -- we are going to put aside the fact that I don't see how this Defendant on the third or fourth could ever win, given that he was begging for drug treatment during his sentencing, so how a resentence would affect the fairness or integrity of this proceeding is beyond my understanding.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: But isn't Justice Breyer right?

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: --No.

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: Not in the Government's view.

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: It becomes a fourth prong question then.

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: And in the Escalante-Reyes case, one of the dissenting opinions attached an appendix in which the Fifth Circuit, in 181 cases, had found that fourth prong met and had found plain error satisfied.

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: But I would think it--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Well, I would say to you that that's more in keeping with the attitude that Justice Kennedy asked about, which is I think most circuit courts believe the fourth prong is more easily met in sentencing than in trial cases.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Whether they are right about that, that's not an issue we are facing today.

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: --The Second Circuit has adopted that rule.

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: But I don't think that we can say that--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Well, what about the -- I mean, that's the question.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The word “ plain ” of course refers by and large to an error that the lower court judge should have caught, so you should have objected.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But why limit it exclusively to that; that is, you have -- you know, they quote the Schooner, Peggy and Chief Justice Marshall and back to the history of Hammurabi, as far as we know, that sometimes there is a case where just simple fairness, plus the fact that the law is now plain, means that the appellate court should treat this person the same as a thousand others who now will be treated according to the new law.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And indeed, you're complicating it even further for the reason that I really meant my question to be aimed at you, you know.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, in fact, the reason that I said that you're going to create distinctions, there will be a case, the fellow is going to go to jail for 50 extra years, the law is plain that he shouldn't, that didn't come about until the appeal.

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: But it is balanced against a very important systemic interest in judicial efficiency.

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: And far from being a horror, that's a necessary corollary of our system--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But, Mr. Wall, your whole argument about judicial efficiency is an incentives argument, and it depends upon the notion that a lawyer is going to change their behavior, a lawyer is going to make an objection that he otherwise wouldn't have made if the rule that Ms. Gilley proposes is accepted.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And this goes back to what Justice Breyer said earlier.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I don't know of a lawyer who would say the following to himself: I'm not going to make this objection because I'm just going to assume that sometime between now and my direct appeal the law is going to change, and it's going to change in my favor, and when it changes, I'm going to be able to make this objection and get over not only prong two but prong three and four of the test, and life will be grand for my client.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Now, who is going to say that?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I mean, this -- basically, what you're saying is we reward the circuits and the judges who don't reach issues, because if the law is unsettled, then if a substantial right is affected, that's so serious that it affects the fairness and integrity of a proceeding, that is not going to result in a reversal.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: It seems to me that if I'm a district court judge or a circuit court judge or anyone else or a circuit court, I would try to avoid as many issues as I could because there's going to be as little set of reversals as possible.

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: Justice Sotomayor--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: And going back to what Justice Ginsburg said, we take cases where the split is 8 to 1, okay, or 8 to 0, because a particular circuit hasn't gotten to -- to an issue.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Does this mean, as Justice Breyer said, that the eight circuits who got it right, the defendants have a Johnson plain-error rule, and the one circuit who just didn't get to it doesn't?

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: --It's -- it's not about rewarding or faulting district courts.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: It seems to me that if I'm a district court judge or a circuit court judge or anyone else or a circuit court, I would try to avoid as many issues as I could because there's going to be as little set of reversals as possible.

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: Justice Sotomayor--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: And going back to what Justice Ginsburg said, we take cases where the split is 8 to 1, okay, or 8 to 0, because a particular circuit hasn't gotten to -- to an issue.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Does this mean, as Justice Breyer said, that the eight circuits who got it right, the defendants have a Johnson plain-error rule, and the one circuit who just didn't get to it doesn't?

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: --It's -- it's not about rewarding or faulting district courts.

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: It's the way our system works.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Now, once I see that, it's like both bookends.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: You don't have to make the objection, and the only time you do is when the law is unclear; and, that being so, we're going to have everybody doing research about how clear the law is one way or the other, which is going to be tough.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But, more importantly, it seems to me what's happening is that 52 is being also used in part to isolate those Peggy Schooner type cases where it is just basically unfair not to apply new law.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And in the words of Justice Marshall, he says that should apply, and sometimes it's unfair not to apply it on the appeal.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And -- and so I don't see how you explain Johnson on your theory.

context.speaker: Sarah E. Harrington

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

context.speaker: John F. Maddrey
context.text: I would agree, Justice Ginsburg.

context.speaker: John F. Maddrey
context.text: The statute--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I didn't hear Justice Ginsburg's question.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The question that Justice Breyer was asking about the 10 percent has already been answered because we were told that if a jury allocated 10 percent to medicals, it would not make any difference, the statute entitles the State to 30 percent.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Basically you are saying the judge would be required to give you your one-third regardless of what the jury said.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Basically you are saying the judge would be required to give you your one-third regardless of what the jury said.

context.speaker: John F. Maddrey
context.text: --Exactly.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Can I go back for a second?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Because I want to show you where I got my perhaps mistaken idea from.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: There is a case called Andrews.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And there is a statement in Andrews, which is a South -- North Carolina case -- which says in certain circumstances, although the statute says just what Justice Scalia says, the lawyer sits there, he takes one-third and pays it to the State.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Then this case has this sentence in it:

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: "Ahlborn controls when there has been a prior determination or stipulation as to the medical expense portion of a plaintiff's settlement. "

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Just answer my question.

context.speaker: John F. Maddrey
context.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Going back to Justice Alito's.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The jury says it's less or more or whatever of -- of the settlement as medical expenses, it doesn't matter what they say, the court can't enter a judgment for that amount, they have to enter a judgment for either the one-third or the full medical expenses.

context.speaker: John F. Maddrey
context.text: They have to enter a judgment, yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The amici were talking about substantially different procedures.

context.speaker: John F. Maddrey
context.text: --Your Honor, the holding in Ahlborn said you can't go beyond the amount represented -- that represents repayment for medicals.

context.speaker: John F. Maddrey
context.text: It didn't say how a State has to or could determine that, and that's the question that's presented.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: But my point is, Justice Kennedy's question was that somehow in that opinion, we approved the North Carolina system.

context.speaker: John F. Maddrey
context.text: Your Honor, I think--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Is there a direct reference to North Carolina's system--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You know, they may say 10 percent is, but who believes that?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You need a proceeding.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That is awfully time-consuming.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And as Justice Kagan suggests, I'm not sure it's going to be very accurate.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I don't think a jury determination is going to be -- is going to be accurate on that score.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And I don't know how you go about determining how much of a settlement is attributable to medical expenses versus other things, especially when the settlement itself says only 10 percent is medical expenses.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: You've said several times that the way you do this is based on the judge's experience and so on with -- with the cases.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: And I think what your -- your friend on the other side is saying is that's pretty much what's going on here except over time -- I mean, would it be all right if over time the judge says, well, typically, sometimes it's 25 percent, sometimes it's 35 percent, over time, it's sort of 33 percent.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: And so we're going to have that as an absolute rule so that we don't have to go through these proceedings every time just to make sure that it's 30 percent rather than 33 percent.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: What's -- I guess it's Justice Kagan's question -- what's wrong with the bright-line rule here?

context.speaker: Christopher G. Browning, Jr.
context.text: --There would be nothing wrong with a rule that creates a presumption.

context.speaker: Christopher G. Browning, Jr.
context.text: What is the problem is, you have cases that are on the extremes like this case where you have absolutely horrendous injuries and a physician who doesn't have the financial wherewithal to pay for the extent of the damages that he caused.

context.speaker: Christopher G. Browning, Jr.
context.text: But moreover, even in that scenario, I think given the language of the North Carolina statute, the State would still be seeking one-third.

context.speaker: Christopher G. Browning, Jr.
context.text: So, if one were to take that route, it would be an extremely treacherous route that you be -- would be not being able to -- to get full -- full recovery from the defendant but still having to be paying a third to the State of North Carolina.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But it would be the defendant who's -- who's -- who's jiggering the system, I mean, not suing for the medical portion simply because the defendant knows that at least some of that portion, if not all of it, would -- would go -- would go to the State.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: So, in a situation such as yours where the total recovery is -- is not going to suffice to cover both pain and suffering and medical expenses, it'd be very intelligent to do what Justice Alito proposed.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And that seems to me a real, I don't know, gaming -- gaming of the system.

context.speaker: Christopher G. Browning, Jr.
context.text: I don't think it would be a gaming of the system, Justice Scalia, if the State, based upon the statute, based upon its previous directives would expect the Medicaid beneficiary to seek recovery of those claims and to remit one-third to the State.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It envisage that a judicial or administrative proceeding would be necessary where a beneficiary and the state cannot agree on what portion of the settlement represents compensation for medical expenses.
